longDescription: Alchemy is an ancient protoscience and philosophical tradition combining elements of chemistry, metallurgy, physics, medicine, astrology, semiotics, mysticism, and spiritualism. Its ultimate goals were the transmutation of base metals into gold, the creation of an elixir of immortality, and the achievement of spiritual perfection.
shortDescription: Mystical practice of transformation seeking the Philosopher's Stone and spiritual perfection
name: Alchemy
safetyWarnings: Historical practice - do not attempt chemical processes without expertise
Focus on spiritual/symbolic alchemy for modern practice

longDescription: Astral projection (or astral travel) is the practice of intentionally inducing an out-of-body experience where consciousness separates from the physical body to explore the astral plane. Found in various esoteric traditions, it involves achieving a relaxed state where the "astral body" or "subtle body" can detach and travel.
shortDescription: Out-of-body experience technique for consciousness exploration beyond the physical
name: Astral Projection

longDescription: Astrology is the study of celestial bodies' movements and their influence on human affairs and natural phenomena. Originating in ancient Babylonia and developed through Greek, Arabic, and European traditions, it uses birth charts, transits, and planetary cycles for divination and personality analysis.
shortDescription: Celestial divination system using planetary positions and zodiac signs for insight
name: Astrology
safetyWarnings: Avoid scaring clients with negative predictions

longDescription: Pranayama is the yogic science of breath control, regulating prana (life force) through specific breathing techniques. Described in classical yoga texts, it forms the fourth limb of Ashtanga Yoga and is essential for meditation, energy work, and spiritual practice.
shortDescription: Yogic breath control techniques for prana regulation and spiritual development
name: Pranayama (Breathwork)
safetyWarnings: Be cautious with retention if heart/lung conditions

longDescription: Ceremonial Magic (also High Magic or Ritual Magic) is a broad term for formal magical practices involving elaborate rituals, precise symbolic gestures, sacred names, and ceremonial tools. Drawing from Hermetic, Kabbalistic, and grimoire traditions, it emphasizes structured ceremonies for spiritual development and working with spiritual entities.
shortDescription: Formal ritual magic using precise ceremonies, symbols, and invocations
name: Ceremonial Magic

longDescription: Chakra work focuses on activating, balancing, and harmonizing the seven primary energy centers (chakras) located along the central channel of the body. Originating in Hindu and Buddhist traditions of India, the chakra system represents a sophisticated map of human consciousness.
shortDescription: 7-chakra energy center system for balancing and awakening spiritual energy
name: Chakra Work
safetyWarnings: Balance all chakras, not just upper ones

longDescription: Chaos Magic is a contemporary magical practice that emerged in England in the 1970s, emphasizing pragmatic techniques over specific traditions or belief systems. Chaos magicians treat belief itself as a tool, adopting and discarding belief systems as needed. The practice focuses on achieving tangible results through sigilization, servitor creation, and gnosis states.
shortDescription: Pragmatic postmodern magic emphasizing belief as a tool and results-focused practice
name: Chaos Magic

firstAttestation.source: Ray Sherwin and Peter J. Carroll

longDescription: The Corpus Hermeticum is a collection of religious and philosophical texts dating from the 2nd-3rd centuries CE, written in Greek and attributed to Hermes Trismegistus. These texts form the foundation of Hermeticism, blending Egyptian, Greek, and early Christian ideas about God, the cosmos, mind, and nature.
shortDescription: Collection of Greco-Egyptian wisdom texts attributed to Hermes Trismegistus
name: Corpus Hermeticum

longDescription: The Emerald Tablet (Tabula Smaragdina) is a cryptic Hermetic text attributed to Hermes Trismegistus, containing the foundational principles of alchemy and Hermetic philosophy in highly condensed form. Its famous maxim "As above, so below" has influenced Western esotericism for centuries.
shortDescription: Compact alchemical and philosophical text containing "As above, so below" principle
name: Emerald Tablet
safetyWarnings: Requires study of alchemy and hermeticism

longDescription: Enochian Magic is a system of ceremonial magic based on the evocation and commanding of spirits, using the Enochian language purportedly received by Dr. John Dee and Edward Kelley in the 16th century. The system includes a complex angelology, four elemental watchtowers, and the Enochian alphabet and language.
shortDescription: Complex angelic magic system using Enochian language and watchtower symbolism
name: Enochian Magic

longDescription: Geomancy is a method of divination that creates 16 possible figures (each made of four lines of single or double points) through random generation. Originating in Arabic lands, it spread to medieval Europe where it was integrated into Hermetic and ceremonial magic traditions.
shortDescription: 16-figure earth divination system using random marks to generate patterns
name: Geomancy

longDescription: The I Ching or Yijing (Book of Changes) is one of the oldest Chinese classical texts and divination systems, dating back over 3,000 years. It consists of 64 hexagrams representing fundamental patterns of change and transformation.
shortDescription: 64-hexagram divination system based on yin-yang dynamics and the Book of Changes
name: I Ching (Yijing)
safetyWarnings: Do not consult frivolously or repeatedly

longDescription: Kundalini Yoga focuses on awakening the kundalini shakti—dormant spiritual energy visualized as a coiled serpent at the base of the spine. Through specific techniques, this energy rises through the chakras, leading to spiritual awakening and enlightenment.
shortDescription: Yogic practice awakening dormant serpent energy at the base of the spine
name: Kundalini Yoga

longDescription: The Kybalion is a 1908 book presenting seven Hermetic principles attributed to Hermes Trismegistus but actually written by "Three Initiates" (likely William Walker Atkinson). While not an ancient text, it has become influential in modern occultism and New Thought movements, presenting principles of Mentalism, Correspondence, Vibration, Polarity, Rhythm, Cause and Effect, and Gender.
shortDescription: Modern text presenting Seven Hermetic Principles for understanding universal laws
name: The Kybalion
safetyWarnings: Modern text, not ancient as claimed
Useful but not traditional Hermetic teaching
Be aware of New Thought influences

longDescription: Meditation encompasses a wide range of practices found across many spiritual traditions, involving techniques to train attention, develop awareness, and cultivate specific mental states. From Buddhist mindfulness to Hindu mantra meditation, from Taoist inner alchemy to Christian contemplative prayer, meditation is a universal human spiritual technology.
shortDescription: Contemplative practice for training awareness, achieving mental clarity, and spiritual development
name: Meditation
safetyWarnings: Mental health conditions may require professional guidance

longDescription: The Middle Pillar exercise is a foundational practice from the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn tradition, working with the central pillar of the Kabbalistic Tree of Life. Practitioners visualize and vibrate divine names associated with five energy centers, circulating divine light through the body.
shortDescription: Kabbalistic energy circulation ritual using Tree of Life sephiroth and divine names
name: Middle Pillar

longDescription: Oracle bone divination (Jiaguwen) was practiced during the Shang Dynasty (c. 1600-1046 BCE) in China. Questions were inscribed on turtle shells or ox shoulder blades, which were then heated until they cracked. The patterns of cracks were interpreted as answers from ancestors or deities.
shortDescription: Ancient Chinese divination using heat-cracked turtle shells and ox scapulae
name: Oracle Bones

longDescription: Practical Kabbalah refers to the magical and theurgical applications of Kabbalistic teachings, distinct from theoretical Kabbalah. It involves the use of divine names, Hebrew letter combinations, amulets, and rituals for healing, protection, and spiritual purposes. While controversial within Judaism, it represents a significant magical tradition.
shortDescription: Jewish magical practice using divine names, Hebrew letters, and Kabbalistic symbolism
name: Practical Kabbalah
safetyWarnings: Requires deep knowledge of Hebrew and Jewish tradition
Work with qualified teacher from tradition
Do not appropriate without cultural context

longDescription: Qigong (氣功) is a holistic system combining slow, deliberate movements, breathing techniques, and meditation to cultivate and balance qi (life force energy). With roots in ancient China, it encompasses thousands of practices for health, martial arts, and spiritual development.
shortDescription: Chinese energy cultivation practice coordinating breath, movement, and awareness
name: Qigong
safetyWarnings: Learn proper form from qualified teacher

longDescription: Reiki is a Japanese healing technique where practitioners channel universal life force energy (ki/qi) through their hands to activate natural healing processes. Developed by Mikao Usui in 1922 after a spiritual experience on Mount Kurama, it has become one of the most popular complementary healing modalities worldwide.
shortDescription: Japanese energy healing system channeling universal life force through hands
name: Reiki
safetyWarnings: Not a substitute for medical care

longDescription: Runes are the letters of ancient Germanic alphabets, particularly the Elder Futhark (24 runes), used both for writing and magical/divinatory purposes. According to Norse mythology, Odin discovered the runes through self-sacrifice, hanging on Yggdrasil for nine days.
shortDescription: Elder Futhark 24-rune divination and magical alphabet from Germanic traditions
name: Runes

longDescription: The Tarot is a complex symbolic system consisting of 78 cards divided into the Major Arcana (22 cards) and Minor Arcana (56 cards). While playing card games using tarot-like decks emerged in 15th-century Italy, the use of Tarot for divination and esoteric purposes developed primarily in the late 18th and 19th centuries.
shortDescription: 78-card divination system combining Major Arcana and Minor Arcana for spiritual insight
name: Tarot
safetyWarnings: Avoid dependency on cards for all decisions
Use as guidance not absolute truth
Do not claim to predict fixed future
